text: A dark, but large cave in the depths of the Motoyama Mountains of Iwo Jima. The hand carved walls show striations of pick axes from many years past. A PHOTOGRAPHER makes notes on his clipboard and takes flash pictures of labeled artifacts laid out on the floor -- a dust covered BOOT, a rusted and dented CANTEEN. A group of JAPANESE EXCAVATORS wearing hard hats with the words “Association of Iwo Jima” emblazoned on them, carefully dig the floor with shovels. The dirt is thrown into wooden boxes with rhythmic THUMPS, and carried out to be sifted. Drenched with sweat and their faces red with exertion, the excavators wither under the humid heat.
How did those soldiers dig out these tunnels in the first place? Exhausted, Excavator #1 has to pause.
Let’s get a rotation in here. He starts to leave.
Wait a minute. His shovel hits something which looks like a LEATHER SATCHEL. The two Excavators take a closer look and carefully dig around the artifact.
as they pierce the black sandy dirt of the beach. They dig in and lift. The voice of PVF. KATSUHIRO SAIGO, in his thirties, reads a letter.

To Hanakg. We soldiers dig. We dig .all day. We dig holes where we are to stand when battle comes. Holes just big enough to stand in. Not wide enough to move forward or to move back. Holes where we are expected to fight and stay in until we die, for die we most likely will.

An entire beach lined with trenches and SOLDIERS digging. The sun beats down on their sweat-drenched backs. SUPERIMPOSE: IWO JIMA ISLAND, JUNE 1944. Other soldiers maneuver artillery pieces into position or work on constructing bunkers and pillboxes -- buried huts for housing machine guns and antitank weapons.

Hanako, now I know what it feels like to dig my own grave. Saigo wipes his face dirtied with the black sand. He has an unrefined look, but with kind eyes and an energetic demeanor. He’s seen enough in life to either make him wise or a wise-ass. A FLAG of the Japanese Navy & Army, bearing the sun motif with banded rays, flutters on the beach encampment. Overhead, a PLANE approaches the island. INT. PLANE HEADED TOWARDS IWO — DAY LT. GENERAL TADAMICHI KURIBAYASHI, fifty-three, staunch and tall, with an air of regality, sits on a bench of the supply plane.

Today, I head for my post where my men are stationed. To avoid detection by the enemy, I take a supply plane and the hour of my arrival remains unannounced. My heart is as strong as that of General Kusonoki who gave his life for Japan 650 years ago at the Minato River.
ke ie
te i  3
Kuribayashi looks out a window as the plane descends.

I hope you and the children are well. I’m sorry I wasn’t able to attend to the kitchen floor before I left. Make sure to have Taro take care of it as those drafts may give you a cold. As the plane approaches Iwo Jima, the island materializes below like a large, brown pork chop. The distinct dome- shaped volcano, Mt. Suribachi, rises up out of the South end.
The black-sanded beach is busy with the activity of soldiers. The men dig at different intervals from one another. PVT. KASHIWARA digs in the hole next to Saigo’s.
Damn this island! The Americans can have it. He continues digging as he mutters.
Nothing grows here, it smells, it’s hot, there are too many damn bugs and there’s no water.
This island is part of Japan’s sacred homeland. :
There’s nothing sacred about this island. CAPTAIN TANIDA, late twenties, and sharply dressed, walks along the trenches inspecting. Kashiwara sees him and tries to warn Saigo.
Hey Saigo! Hey! Saigo ignores Kashiwara as he continues grumbling.
We should just give this island to the Ameritans, and then we can go home.
What did you say, soldier? Saigo finally sees the Captain and puts his shovel down. Salutes.
Sir, I said if we beat the Americans, then we can go home. Captain Tanida looks at Kashiwara.
You there. Is that what he said? Kashiwara seems helpless. There is a moment of hesitation.
Yes, sir.

ADMIRAL OHSUGI, forties, waits patiently on the beach along with his OFFICER STAFF MEMBERS. Finally, the war-torn plane drones in for a landing. It lands safely on the landing strip. Kuribayashi steps off onto the tarmac. LT. FUJITA, twenties, Kuribayashi’s personal aide, follows behind him. . They makes their way to Ohsugi and exchange salutes.
Welcome, General Kuribayashi. I’m Admiral Ohsugi. They bow politely.
How long have you been waiting here for me? Ohsugi checks his watch.
Three hours, ~sér.
Sorry to hear. They wouldn’t allow me to wire my arrival after what happened to Admiral Yamamoto.
I understand, sir. Kuribayashi turns to Lt. Fujita.
This is my aide, Lieutenant Fujita. Admiral Ohsugi and Lt. Fujita bow to each other. Ohsugi touches his stomach and grimaces.
What’s the matter, Admiral? You don’t look very well.
Oh, it’s nothing, sir. The water here does not agree with me.
Sorry to hear that. Ohsugi motions the way.
This way to your quarters.
Admiral, I want to make a round of the island first.
Shall I fetch a jeep?

No, let’s walk. Walking’s good for the health. It might be just what you need, Ohsugi- He chuckles, but Ohsugi does not look pleased. They walk together, while the members of the staff walk a respectful 3 paces behind.
esta re
Kuribayashi stops in front of a view of the cone-shaped volcano, MT. SURTBACHT on the South end of the island.
I could see it from the plane. Mt. Suribachi. That’s the first place the Americans will want to take, Ohsugi.
Captain Tanida quickly finds a stick and whips Saigo and Kashiwara with it. The two grimace with the pain. Tanida doesn’t notice when Kuribayashi and his entourage pass by behind him.
You no good peasants! Scums! Kuribayashi approaches Captain Tanida, who immediately stands at attention and stops beating Saigo and Kashiwara.
Captain, what are you doing?
These soldiers were conspiring with unpatriotic words, sir. Kuribayashi looks over at the haggard looking soldiers.
I see. And Captain, do you have such an excess of soldiers that you can put two of them out of commission? Captain Tanida is hesitant.
No, sir.
Then stop beating them. Deny their lunch rations instead. Ohsugi and Tanida look at each other, miffed.
A good captain uses his brain, not just his whip. :
Yes, sir. a
And what is all this?
This? Trenches, sir.
Why are the men digging trenches here? Tanida looks to Ohsugi once again for support.
This is where the Americans are expected to land, sir. Kuribayashi looks at the men digging.
Have them stop immediately.
But, sir...

If you had studied Tarawa, you would know that concentrating our defenses at the beach would be futile. Captain Tanida is hesitant. Kuribayashi gives him a firm look. Captain Tanida turns towards the soldiers.
Stop digging! The men stop and look up, surprised. Kuribayashi turns to Captain Tanida.
And Captain, make sure these men get proper breaks. They look like they’re from Mars.
The soldiers sit on the sand, eating out of their mess kits. All except Saigo and Kashiwara who watch them hungrily.
b

Kashiwara rubs his stomach. - © KASHTWARA Just a8 well. My stomach’s been bothering me anyway. A soldier on water duty comes by with a pitcher, and they are allowed a tiny cupful, which they take gratefully.
A toast to General Kuribayashi. A fine commander. Kashiwara drinks as well.
Mmmmm. Better than sake. PVT. NOZAKI, another soldier in his thirties, comes to join them.
I heard he lived in America. Maybe that’s why he doesn’t want us digging trenches. Maybe he likes the Americans.
No, stupid. He studied the Americans, so now he knows how to beat them.
I heard from someone in the 204th that another general was supposed to command the island, but he didn’t want the job, so Premier Tojo gave it to Kuribayashi instead.
You hear a lot of things, Nozaki, but your ears are full of wax! Nozaki brushes him off.
Anyway, you can’t trust anyone from the 204th. They’re part of the Navy. I think this Kuribayashi must be a superb general. Look, we're not digging those damn trenches in the sand anymore, are we?
Kashiwara’s stomach makes a large GROWLING noise.
Kuribayashi inspects a map of Iwo Jima with defense plans marked. Admiral Ohsugi and a stern looking Naval officer, LIEUTENANT ITO, are in the room with him.
How many planes do we have?
41 Zekes and 13 bombers.
Is that all?
We sent 66 planes to reinforce the fleet at Saipan. Kuribayashi looks grave.
We will have to rely on support from the Combined Fleet. He turns his attention to defense maps.
These are your defense plans?
Yes, sir.
And what about the army troops? Where will they be stationed? Ohsugi hesitates.
Well, sir, I don’t know exactly. They are under the command of Col... Adachi. Kuribayashi looks at him, surprised.
You haven't coordinated your plans?
Col. Adachi prefers that we do not interfere*with each other’s chain of command.
This is no time for childish games, Admiral. This is war. Ohsugi feels the sting. Kuribayashi sighs and goes back to looking at the map.
This will not work. You are concentrating all your efforts on the beaches. Move the artillery to higher ground.
But sir, we just had them moved down to the beaches.
Well, move them back up. We’1l need fortifications at Suribachi. Coordinate with Col. Adachi and have them start immediately.
Yes, sir.
Admiral Ohsugi walks briskly with Lt. Ito, annoyed. ADMIRAL OHSUGI . This one’s trouble. Lt. Ito nods in agreement.
Army commanders usually are, sir.
Captain Tanida barks commands like a fierce little pit bull. Saigo, Kashiwara and Nozaki stand to attention. 10. 10
Our new ordersyhave come in for the day! Prepare for relocation!
The soldiers dig at the base of the volcano. The men are stripped to the waist in the heat. Now the dirt they dig is more like lava, still steaming with heat.
It stinks. Saigo lifts up a dirt-full and some of it falls on his back.
Damn Kuribayashi!
Shhhh!
Come on! Dig! Put your backs into it. Saigo mutters to himself.

Kuribayashi inspects A MAP on the wall highlighting areas once occupied at the height of the Japanese Empire in 1943, The “Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere.” The area stretches over a vast circle over the Pacific. Covered with pins of Japanese flags, the map shows locations of strategic forces. White flags represent areas won back by the Allied forces. The white flags encroach on the Japanese flags.
Under curfew, the streets of Tokyo are mostly dark and unlit. CAPTAIN IWASAKI, a stern looking Kempeitai officer patrols the street.
te

Next to him is YOICHI. SHIMIZU, 17. Everything about Shimizu is orderly and pristine, from his shiny boots, to his perfectly .alignéd cap. Both wear a WHITE BAND on their left arm with kanji characters, “Ken” (law) and “Hei” (soldier) inscribed on them.

To mother. I am proud to say I graduated training with flying colors and I will be training under the guidance of Captain Iwasaki. It fills my heart with joy to serve my Emperor and the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere. You can rest assured there won't be any spies or Communists under my watch. Thank you for the rice crackers, but please don’t send anymore. We must all conserve our food rations for the war effort. Luxury is the enemy. Saving is the road to victory. A BICYCLIST rides through the main street, ringing his bell. Captain Iwasaki yells at the Bicyclist as he passes them by.
You there! The Bicyclist halts.
You should not be riding right in the middle of the street like that. What if there were an air raid or a military convoy coming through here? The Bicyclist looks frightened. He bows in compliance.
I’m very sorry, sir.
Get off to one side there. The Bicyclist complies. Officer Iwasaki turns to Shimizu.
Remember, Shimizu, as Kempeitai, you have all the authority, so don’t be intimidated by a person's age. You have complete control.
Yes, sir. They arrive at, an office building with a signage Chuo Koron Magazine and bust the door open.
Shimizu roughly rummages through PAPERS. A JOURNALIST, late forties, watches nervously, while Captain Iwasaki stands before him.
What have I done?
You are suspected of violating the Peace Preservation Law. Shimizu continues to go through papers and magazines, throwing useless ones on the floor.
Tell me which article it was. I’m sure I have complied to all the rules --
Be quiet! The Journalist stands up.
Look, I have a family to support. Just let me know what it was and I'll retract the article. He takes out his wallet and lays out his cash on the table. Shimizu looks at the cash, disgusted.
Do you think we can be bribed? How dare you insult us!
Shimizu, I’1l find the articles. Take care®of him. Shimizu nods in compliance and strong-arms the Journalist.
Just a minute.. Shimizu leads him out the door as he protests. Captain Iwasaki deftly takes the money off the table and pockets it. Then he confiscates copies of the magazine Chuo Koron.
PRIVATE FIRST CLASS YAMAZAKI mans the POSTAL TENT, relaxing with a copy of a magazine. Saigo walks to him and hands over a letter.
Another letter? You know that the mail only goes out when there’s a boat available, don’t you? Saigo laughs, ‘embarrassed.
I have a lot of family.
Then how come all your letters are addressed to your wife? Saigo gives him a look.
Nosey.
Here let me do you a favor. Otherwise, your letters will never make it through. He opens Saigo’s letter.
Hey, what are you doing? 4 15
I used to workeat the Office of Censorship in Tokyo, you know, before I got transferred.
Transferred? You mean demoted? Yamazaki tries to ignore the last comment. He reads the letter.
(reading) “To Hanako. We soldiers dig...” No, no, no. This will never pass. He starts crossing off lines of Saigo’s letter.
Hey! Private Yamazaki continues blacking out lines. Most of Saigo’s letter is crossed out as he reads/mumbles the rest of the letter. He suddenly LAUGHS out loud.
Give me that back! Yamazaki finishes crossing off the letter so that the only lines that remain are "To Hanako,” and "Hope you are doing well.”
There. You’ll thank me for this later, Saigo. He seals the letter back up. Saigo grumbles as he leaves.

Saigo and the men have rifle practice. Each soldier gets their turn at hitting a bulls-eye. Kuribayashi stands watching from a distance. One of the soldier’s gun jams and he fiddles with it. Another is slow to aim.
Faster!
Ses tittinte! 16 17 16.

Kuribayashi continues to watch, disappointment registering on his face. © When it’s Saigo’s turn, he aims his rifle. At the last minute, he jerks his gun. His shot is way off the mark. Captain Tanida storms up to him and shouts in his ear.
Saigo, are you blind? Can’t you see the target? Even my 6 year old could shoot better than you do. Saigo bows his head in apology.
Do it again. Saigo fumbles. He aims his rifle and once again, his shot is way off the mark. Captain Tanida hits the back of his head.
You‘re an embarrassment! -You’re a poor excuse for a soldier. Tonight, you will clean the boots of your entire troop. Go to the rear! Kuribayashi turns to Lt. Fujita.
Better they should learn to clean their guns properly rather than their boots.

General Kuribayashi, with a company of army soldiers, marches through the local village. Ever his shadow, Lt. Fujita marches alongside him. It’s a small town with a dusty main street, a bar, general store and single-story houses bedecked with banners. Children, women and grandparents run out to greet the men with Rising Sun flags and cheer them on. Kuribayashi notices a collection of idle TANKS in the village with a few ARMY MECHANICS working on them.
i. f
What are thosestanks doing here?
Those are out of commission, sir. They are waiting for parts.
Waiting for parts? How long have they been like this.
I have been told about a month, sir. Kuribayashi looks again at the tanks. A LITTLE BOY of about four plays in the foreground with toy tanks.

The streets are jammed with cars, HONKING, and stalled in traffic. Kuribayashi sits on a park bench with HARVARD UNIVERSITY in the b.g., a stack of textbooks beside him. Kuribayashi sketches a picture of a car in a notebook.

To Taro, from Father. This is a picture of a car. America is filled with cars. I have to be very careful when crossing the streets. Cars come from every direction. Even my maid has a car. Japan has a lot of catching up to do with America. Kuribayashi looks up again at the traffic jam.
Taro, are you minding your mother? I wish you were here with me. Kuribayashi pulls out a picture of his young son, TARO. aa END OF FLASHBACK.
Kuribayashi is still focused on the young boy playing in front of the idle tanks. He turns to Fujita.
These civilians need to be evacuated as soon as possible.
Yes, sir.
Saigo is busy cleaning stacks of shoes. Kashiwara approaches him with his own boots.
Saigo, I know that you must be a better shot than that after a year and a half. Saigo doesn’t look up from his cleaning.
I have no aim, that’s all. Kashiwara hesitates for a moment, shakes his head and leaves his boots.
Kuribayashi with walking stick in hand, makes his way briskly across the beach. He sees the mountains in the Northern hills and heads. over towards them.
Kuribayashi stares at the mountains, starts to climb up one of them. He carefully ascends and peers into one of the natural caves. .
The village is now an empty ghost town. The flags have all been taken down, turning the city from colorful to monochromatic.
Be
Only bits of litter remain, scattering in the wind.
Saigo and other members of his troop tear down a school house, collecting the wood into piles. Captain Tanida inspects another nearby structure.

We can use the wood from this one as well. All the men stop when they hear the sound of a GALLOPING HORSE. They turn to see BARON TAKEICHI NISHI, tall, handsome and gallant, riding with gusto towards them.

Hanako, we have a celebrity in our midst. Do you remember Baron Nishi, the Olympic gold medalist in horse jumping? He has just arrived from Tokyo and is stationed here as Commander of the 26th Tank Regiment. The men watch as he rides full speed, and hurdles over a fence. A study in grace and agility. The men CLAP. Baron Nishi smiles and salutes them as he rides on.
Get back to work, men. Baron Nishi nearly mows Captain Tanida over as he gallops away.

Lieutenant Colonel Nishi is very handsome, so I’m sure the rumors of his womanizing skills must be true, but there are no women left on the island to woo. He is friendly with the troops and sometimes talks casually among them. Strange for a Lieutenant.
Kuribayashi walks along the sand with his walking stick. He stops when he sees Baron Nishi approaching, sand flying from his horse's heels.
Baron Nishi dismounts his horse, his spurred boots 20. 24 CLINKING as they hit the ground. He salutes Kuribayashi. General Kuribayashi walks up to Baron Nishi and they shake hands like Westerners.
Lieutenant Colonel Nishi. I used to be a cavalryman myself, you know.
Yes, of course. I’ve been looking forward to serving under you. One who understands horses the way I do.
Those were the days, when soldiers could ride in on horses. Not these mechanized contraptions. Kuribayashi admires the horse.
I could send for another horse and we could ride together, General.
I’m afraid my riding days are over, Nishi. But tell me about this famous horse of yours that you won the Olympics with.
My stallion, Uranus? + He pulls out a picture of Uranus, a stallion of Anglo- Norman stock, and shows it to Kuribayashi.
That’s a fine horse.

The Italians thought I was doing them a favor, getting rid of him to me. No one could tame the beast, but I told them ‘If that’s a really headstrong horse, it’s just the one for me, a headstrong man.’ They share a laugh.
I’m dying for: some news from the mainland on the war effort. We mostly just hear what they filter on the radio broadcasts.
I understand. It’s hard to know what’s really going on these days.
Dine with me tonight. And if you have brought any sake back with you, that would be a double welcome.

I think that can be arranged, sir. INT. OFFICER’S QUARTERS - NIGHT 25 Kuribayashi and Baron Nishi sit at a table with cups of sake before them. The COOK enters and serves them plates of fish and rice. He then continues to place empty plates on the table.
Is that still really necessary?
Regulations, sir. Baron Nishi looks at Kuribayashi questioningly.
I have told our cook that all officers will have the same rations and food as our men. The Cook looks flustered.
It is not right. Officers should not eat the same food.
Apparently, military regulations dictates that officers must be served at least three dishes.
That's right. At least three dishes. This is a travesty, sir. I am very ashamed. The Cook finishes placing the empty dishes.
So as a compromise, I told him he could bring out empty dishes. The Cook bows and exits.
He’s a stubborn son of a bitch. I had to give in to him. kuribayashi and Nishi LAUGH. Kuribayashi jovially pours another cup of sake in Baron Nishi’s cup.
We will defeat the enemy this time, Nishi. It will be different from past island battles.
I'm sure it will be, sir.
After all, Iwo Tou is part of Japanese soil. Kuribayashi sips his sake.
When the enemy arrive, we will contain them, and then our Combined Fleet will take them out. Blast them back to America. Baron Nishi turns grave and is silent for a moment.
General, there is no longer any Combined Fleet.
What do you mean?
I guess you haven’t heard about what happened with Operation A-Go ten days ago. (MORE)

BARON NISHI (cont'd) Most of Admiral Ozawa’s carrier planes and float planes were destroyed off the Marianas. We still have some scattered naval forces, but there will be no striking power from the air, or sea for that matter. Kuribayashi looks dark, then laughs.
You must be drunk. This island is under the jurisdiction of the city of Tokyo. We'll get our support.

If you want my honest opinion, the best thing to do would be to sink this island to the bottom of the sea. Baron Nishi takes a large gulp of the sake. Kuribayashi is speechless, his jovial mood wiped out.
And yet, you still came.
Well, I figured your men were going to need all the tanks I could bring. This brings a light smile back.

Kuribayashi looks over the strategic plans. He slowly removes all air attack force plans from the table model. He stands over the table in grave contemplation, then angrily pulls strategic PLAN PAPERS off the wall.
Kuribayashi strides along the beach with Fujita behind him.
This beach is wide. Yes, the enemy must land here. They have no alternative. Kuribayashi rushes the beach. Fujita watches him, perplexed.
Fujita!
Sir!
Run along the beach there.
Six?

Like you’re one of the Americans. Go on. Which direction would you take? Fujita contemplates for a minute, then rushes up towards the airfield. Kuribayashi quickly takes up a position and aims his walking stick at Fujita, pretending to shoot, moves around, looks for another vantage point. He looks at the surroundings, measuring where the best positions would be.
Okay, come from the other side. Fujita complies. Kuribayashi takes up another position and mock shoots him again.
Kashiwara and Saigo stare in awe at the beach activity.
I think your general is a bit nuts. Captain Tanida strides up the slopes barking commands.
Break time is over! Back to work! The men get up immediately. Kashiwara suddenly bowls over from a cramp. Saigo looks at him concerned.
You don’t look so good. Are you all right?
t fs ie fe fr t
By
It’s fine. Jugt the damn water, I’m sure. But I really need to go. He quickly makes his way to a discrete location behind the mountain.

Kuribayashi walks along the hillside with a gaggle of Officers struggling to keep up with him. Admiral Ohsugi, aging 57-year-old COLONEL ADACHI and MAJ. GENERAL SATO are among them. Finally, Kuribayashi comes to a stop and turns to the officers. ‘ KURIBAYASHI Our strategy will be to take a defensive position and use the terrain to our advantage. We will build caves and tunnels in the mountains, place our artillery along this ridge and Suribachi.
What about the beaches?
The men will have a clear view of the beaches from Suribachi and Motoyama. There is no need to fortify the beaches.
General Kuribayashi, you must understand that the trenches are the first line of defense. We must resume work on the beaches.

General, do you know how many cars America produces in a year? Five million. Five million cars, General. The American forces and their technological advancements should not be underestimated. The Americans will cross the beaches eventually and the soldiers’ lives will be needlessly wasted there.
It's inevitable that men will die. But I’ve never heard of an island operation without a line of defense at the beaches.
And how long did our guns last along the beaches at Saipan and Guam? Will you please show me just how effective the beach pillboxes at Tarawa were? The officers are silent for a moment.
So we build tunnels and caves in the mountains?
It will be a futile waste of time. a The men cannot dig through a fos mountain. Besides, what kind of war is fought in caves?
The strategy should be to force the ships in for a heavy air attack.
I agree. That makes the most sense. We will have support from our Combined Fleet. Kuribayashi is quiet for a beat.
We can no longer count on our Combined Fleet.
What do you mean?
The Combined Fleet has been broken.
The officers look at each other with gravity.
What’s more, “Isreceived an order on the wire this morning that all our remaining planes are to be sent back to Tokyo to defend the mainland.
We won't be able to last five days without air support.

We will hold the island as long as possible, no matter the outcome. Once the Americans take Iwo Tou, they will have a clear route for their bombing runs. But if we can draw out the battle, hold this island for at least 20 days, the Americans will think twice about attacking Japan.

RAIN comes down in torrents, a tropical storm in the midst of ‘the heat. Tarps that have been put up to collect the water fill up with the rain. Soldiers transfer the water from the tarp into buckets and haul them to camp.
Another rainy day on the island.
Shimizu steps off an air carrier along with other soldiers. He looks around him, carrying his pack.
fo mother, today I am to join my new unit. I know you have been wondering about my transfer. This is something I cannot discuss now, but I will explain to you some day.

32 INT. TROOP’S CAVE..—_DAY (DEC. 1944) The soldiers lie on their bedrolls, reading books, 32 writing letters or mending their uniforms. Even though it’s winter, the men are stripped to their undershirts and try to fan themselves in the heat. Saigo reads a BOOK with pictures of Egypt on the cover. Saigo shows Nozaki a page from the book.
Look at this picture.
That’s some fancy castle.
You know who that castle was made for? Somebody who was already dead.
They must have had a lot of money back then to make a castle. like that for a dead person. Why are you reading a book about Egypt anyway? We’re never going to war over there.
(ignoring) We'll be lucky if we even get a hole in the ground when we’re dead.
Don’t talk about that. It’s bad luck. Shimizu enters the cave. Despite the rain, his uniform still looks crisp and clean.
Here comes the new recruit.
Is this the 312th?
That’s right. Saigo continues reading his book.
Se NOZAKI I’m Nozaki. ~Teis is Saigo.
Shimizu, Yoichi.
You can put your bedroll there, Shimizu. He points to an empty space. Shimizu is about to put his bedroll down, but Saigo tries to prevent him.
There’s another empty space at the back end of the cave.
{to Shimizu) Don’t mind him. His friend Kashiwara just died. That used to be his spot. Shimizu methodically puts his bedroll out, where Kashiwara’s spot used to be.
But. we are all going to die. That’s our plan, isn’t it?
If it serves the country, it is a death of honor.
Kashiwara died of honorable | dysentery.
Where are you from, Shimizu?
From Kanagawa-ken.
Kanagawa-ken. Ozawa is from there, aren’t you? . OZAWA, a young soldier in his twenties, nods his head.
That’s right. Where did you train? Maybe we were at the same camp.
i i t
Shimizu is hesitant. “= suimrzu No, I trained in Tokyo.
Beak
I trained in Tokyo, too. What camp was it? Shimizu is hesitant again. é SHIMIZU The Koho Kimmu Yoin Yoseijo. Everyone becomes silent. Shimizu turns to continue unpacking his bedroll.
Nozaki quickly leaves his vicinity and sidles up to Saigo.
Why do you think they put a Kempeitai in our unit?
He’s not wearing the white arm band. He’s not Kempeitai.
He went to the Kempeitai military academy.
Maybe he flunked out. Nozaki notices a holstered PISTOL on Shimizu's belt.
i He acts like a Kempeitai. And : look at his holster. That’s not standard issue. And are riflemen even supposed to have pistols? He’s been put here to spy on us.
Why would he spy on us?
Maybe it’s those letters you’ve been writing. JI think you should be careful what you say, Saigo. \

Saigo looks worried. They watch Shimizu. He sits down and pulls out a small migror, checks his closely cropped hair. He jumps up suddenly with a YELL. A CENTIPEDE crawls on him. Nozaki and Saigo try to suppress their smirks. Shimizu looks embarrassed. He stomps on the insect angrily. ,
The soldiers line up for their lunchtime rations. They each get a bowl of soup with weeds floating in them.
